children.name: to make a loud high noise
scream
children.definition: to make a loud high noise with your voice because you are hurt, frightened, excited etcSYN shriek: la hét
examples: After the first few shots, people started screaming.
a screaming baby
scream with/in
She jumped to her feet, screaming in terror.
He was draggedkicking and screamingto a nearby van.

children.name: scream loudly
examples: I just screamed as loudly as I could.

children.name: scream wildly
children.definition: in a loud and uncontrolled way
examples: Poor George, screaming wildly, was carried upstairs by his father.

children.name: scream hysterically
children.definition: in a completely uncontrolled way
examples: Some of the girls started screaming hysterically.

children.name: scream with laughter/delight
examples: She threw her head back and screamed with laughter.

children.name: scream in/with pain
examples: We could hear her screaming in pain.

children.name: scream in terror/agony etc
examples: He screamed in fear and panic, and banged frantically on the door.

children.name: scream your head off
children.definition: scream a lot
examples: At least the idiot wasn’t panicking and screaming his head off.

children.name: scream blue murderinformal
children.definition: scream very loudly with fear or anger
examples: She flew into a rage and screamed blue murder at him.

children.name: shriek
children.definition: to make a very high loud sound, especially because you are afraid, angry, excited, or in painSYN scream: la hét
examples: They were dragged from their homes, shrieking and weeping.
He shrieked in agony.

children.name: shriek with excitement/laughter/fear etc
examples: The children began shrieking with hysterical laughter.
A group of students were shrieking with laughter.

children.name: screech
children.definition: to shout loudly in an unpleasant high voice because you are angry, afraid, or excited:rét lên, rít lên
examples: Sue grabbed him, screeching, and started hitting him with her fists.

children.name: ‘Get out!’ she screeched angrily. ‘I hate you!’
examples: ‘Look out!’ she screeched.
Theyscreeched with laughter.

children.name: screech at
examples: Maria suddenly started screeching at Bruno.
She screeched at me to take off my muddy shoes.

children.name: squeal
children.definition: to make a sudden very high screaming sound, because you are excited, amused, frightened, or in pain:ré lên
examples: The children squealed and fought among themselves.
‘Don’t you dare!’ Bobby squealed.
‘Let me go!’ she squealed.

children.name: squeal with excitement/laughter/delight/pain etc
examples: The boy squealed with pain and surprise.
They all tumbled into the water, squealing with delight.
The children squealed with delight.

children.name: yelp
children.definition: to give a short cry, especially because you have just been hurt:hét lên
examples: The boy grinned, and then yelped as someone hit him in the back.
Sophie yelped with pain and dropped the pan.

children.name: shout
children.definition: UKto call out loudlySYN scream:

children.name: shout in pain/anger/frustration etc
examples: Al shouted in pain.

children.name: shout
children.definition: to say sth very loudly, because you want to make sure that sb hears you, or because you are angry or excited →scream,yell:
examples: There’s no need to shout! I can hear you!

children.name: shout abuse/insults
examples: He was surrounded by a group of boys who shouted abuse at him.

children.name: shout obscenities
examples: They came to his apartment, shouting obscenities and threatening him.

children.name: shout slogans
examples: They were carrying placards and shouting slogans.

children.name: shout orders
examples: The lieutenant was shouting orders at the workmen.

children.name: shout sb’s name
examples: Then she heard Ferdinando shout her name.

children.name: shout a warning
examples: The man had shouted a warning to other passengers just before the blast.

children.name: shout for help
examples: I opened my mouth to shout for help.

children.name: shout sth angrily‘
examples: Don’t touch me!’ he shouted angrily.

children.name: shout sth loudly
examples: He hears the voice of his downstairs neighbor shouting loudly.

children.name: shout yourself hoarse
children.definition: shout until your throat is sore
examples: Matthew shouted himself hoarse until he was discovered.

children.name: shout of the top of your voice
children.definition: shout as loudly as possible
examples: 'Watch out!' he shouted at the top of his voice.

children.name: scream and shout
examples: People were screaming and shouting in the streets.

children.name: shout at
examples: I wish you’d stop shouting at the children.

children.name: shout for
examples: We could hear themshouting for help.
‘Watch out!’ she shouted, as the car started to move.

children.name: shout sth at sb
examples: He was shouting insults at the lorry driver.

children.name: shout sth to sb
examples: ‘He’s down here!’ she shouted to Alison.

children.name: shout sth out/shout out sth
examples: Linda leant out of the widow and shouted out my name.

children.name: yell
children.definition: to shout very loudly, for example because you are very angry or excited, or because you want to get someone’s attention.Yellis more informal thanshout:Hét (ít trang trọng)
examples: ‘Don’t touch me,’ she yelled.
The music blaring in the bar was forcing us both to yell to be heard.
yell at
The children were yelling at each other across the street.
Don’t you yell at me like that!
yell at sb to do sth
They yelled at him to stop.
yell (out) in surprise/pain etc
Clare yelled in pain as she fell.
He could hear Pete yellingat the top ofhisvoice(= very loudly ).
yell out sth/yell sth out
He opened the door and yelled out ‘Anybody home?’

children.name: scream
children.definition: (alsoscream out) to shout sth in a very loud high voice because you are angry or frightenedSYN yell:hét lên
examples: ‘Get out!’ she screamed.
He screamed out her name.

children.name: scream for
examples: I screamed for help.

children.name: scream at
examples: He screamed at her to go away.
The crowd continued toscream abuseat him.
Maria felt like screaming at her husband.

children.name: raise your voice U
children.definition: raise your voice to speak more loudly than usual because you are angry about sth: lớn tiếng
examples: I never heard my father raise his voice in his life.

children.name: raise your voice at/to
examples: Don’t you raise your voice at me!

children.name: raised voicesthe sound ofpeople talking loudly because they are angry
examples: We heard raised voices coming from the next room, and then a cry.

children.name: cry
children.definition: written to shout sth loudly, especially because you are feeling strong emotions such as pain or excitement: kêu lên
examples: ‘I can’t move,’ Lesley cried. ‘I think I’ve broken my leg.
‘Come and see what I’ve found!’ Kurt cried.
cry out[I] written C2
‘Careful!’ she cried out. ‘There’s a snake!’
cry out in fear/pain/surprise etc
Chris fell, crying out in pain.

children.name: roar
children.definition: writtento shout in a loud deep voicebecause you are extremely angry or want to frighten sb:gầm lên
examples: Suddenly the teacher roared my name across the classroom.
‘You idiot!’ he roared.

children.name: roar at
examples: ‘Get down and don’t move,’ the man roared at her.

children.name: bawl
children.definition: to shout very loudly and rudely in order to make sure that people hear what you are saying:nói, la oang oang
examples: ‘Stop that thief!’ he bawled at the top of his voice.
One of the prison guards was bawling orders across the yard.

children.name: bawl at
examples: That couple next door are always shouting and bawling at each other.

children.name: bellow
children.definition: writtento shout in a loud deep voice, especially when you want a lot of people to hear you : rống lên
examples: He was bellowing orders at the soldiers.
‘Be quiet!’ the teacher bellowed.
The officer in charge was bellowing instructions through a loudspeaker
bellow at
Then the referee started to blow his whistle and bellow at me.

children.name: shriek
children.definition: to say something in a high loud voice because you are excited, afraid, or angrySYN scream: hét lên
examples: ‘I’m pregnant,’ she shrieked.

children.name: shriek at
examples: ‘I’ll kill you,’ Anne shrieked at him.
The two women shrieked at one another over the noise of the machines.

children.name: shout
children.definition: a loud call that expresses anger, excitement etc, or is made in order to get sb’s attention: tiếng la hét
examples: As we got near the stadium, we could hear the shouts of the crowd.

children.name: an angry shout
examples: Her speech was interrupted by angry shouts from the audience.

children.name: a shout of excitement/joy/pleasure etc
examples: Just then Angie burst in with a shout of excitement.

children.name: give a shout
examples: He gave a shout of joy as he realised he’d won the race.

children.name: scream
children.definition: a sudden loud shout or cry that expresses fear, excitement etc:tiếng la hét
examples: We could hear screams coming from the burning building.
We heard screams coming from the flat.

children.name: a loud scream
examples: Suddenly I heard a loud scream.

children.name: a shrill/piercing/high-pitched scream
children.definition: with a very high sound
examples: The sound of gunfire mingled with the shrill screams of the injured.

children.name: a bloodcurdling scream
children.definition: very frightening
examples: With a blood-curdling scream, he threw himself at Paul.

children.name: a terrified scream
children.definition: by someone who is terrified
examples: I let out a terrified scream and scuttled down the stairs.

children.name: a terrible scream
children.definition: by someone suffering great pain or fear
examples: We were woken late that night by the most terrible screams.

children.name: a little scream
examples: Mrs Wood gave a little scream.

children.name: a muffled/stifled scream
children.definition: made quieter, for example by putting a hand over someone’s mouth
examples: No one heard her muffled screams.

children.name: let out a scream
examples: He let out a piercing scream.

children.name: give a scream
examples: She gave a scream of delight.

children.name: a scream of laughter/delight
examples: We could hear the children’s screams of laughter.

children.name: a scream of pain/terror/agony
examples: My screams of terror awoke my parents.

children.name: a scream of fear/pain/delight etc
examples: A gun went off, and I heard a scream of fear from inside the room.

children.name: yell
children.definition: a very loud shout that expresses great anger, excitement etc or is made in order to get sb’s attention:tiếng la lớn
examples: A great yell went up from the crowd. Liverpool had scored.
a loud/great yell
Suddenly there was a loud/great yell from the bathroom.
a yell of alarm/fear/anger/ surprise/delight/triumph etc
Steve could no longer prevent a yell of frustration.
Dan gave a yell of delight when Larsson scored.
give/let out a yell
Christine gave a yell of alarm as blood spurted from the wound
She let out a yell when she saw me.

children.name: roar
children.definition: a very loud deep shout, especially one that expresses anger, pain, amusement, or excitement:tiếng gầm thét
examples: I love to hear the roar of the crowd at a Blue Jays baseball game.

children.name: a roar of anger/pain/laughter etc
examples: There were roars of laughter coming from the living room.
I shall never forget his roar of anguish on hearing the terrible news.

children.name: cry
children.definition: a shouted word or phrase :tiếng kêu la
examples: cry of
As they left the stage there were cries of ‘More! More!’
At last, there was a cry of ‘Silence!’, and everyone looked towards the door.
cry for
cry for helpsth sb says or does that shows that they are very unhappy and need help :
I think taking the pills was a cry for help.
We heard a child’s cries for help coming from the river.
Fortunately, a passerby heard hiscries for help.

children.name: cheer
children.definition: a shout of happiness, praise, approval, or encouragementOPP boo: tiếng reo hò, cổ vũ
examples: A deafening cheer rose from the crowd as the band walked onto the stage.
The final whistle was greeted with triumphant cheers from players and spectators.

children.name: give a cheer
examples: Let’s all give a big cheer for the newly married couple! Hip, hip, hooray!
So let’sgive a cheerto the kids who passed their exams.

children.name: a cheer goes up
examples: A greatcheer went upfrom the crowd.

children.name: shriek
children.definition: a loud high sound made because you are frightened, excited, angry etc :tiếng la hét
examples: I was woken up by a loud shriek from the bathroom.

children.name: a shriek of delight/laughter
examples: With a shriek of delight, she threw herself into the water.
Almost before he started speaking they all burst into shrieks of laughter.

children.name: with a shriek
examples: With a shriek of delight, Jean hugged Maggie.

children.name: give/let out a shriek
examples: Ella let out a piercing shriek.

children.name: squeal
children.definition: a sudden high screaming sound, when frightened or excited:tiếng kêu ré lên
examples: Suddenly there was a bump and an awful squeal.

children.name: squeals of delight/joy/laughter etc
examples: The sight of the food brought squeals of delight from the children.
She gave a squeal of laughter.
There was a squeal of brakes.

children.name: yelp
children.definition: a short sharp high cry which you make, especially because you have just been hurt

children.name: give/let out a yelp of pain/dismay/surprise etc
examples: The water was hotter than she had expected, and she gave an involuntary yelp.
She jumped back from the fire with a sudden yelp of pain.

children.name: to say sth suddenly or unexpectedly
exclaim
children.definition: to say something suddenly and loudly because you are angry, surprised, or excited:kêu lên, la lên
examples: ‘What a beautiful house!’ she exclaimed.
‘Aha'!', he exclaimed triumphantly. ’We knew you’d come".

children.name: come out with
children.definition: to suddenly say sth, in an unplanned way, which other people find unusual or surprising:thốt lên
examples: It was strange to hear a little old lady come out with a swear word like that.
I don’t want to make a speech -- I’ll only come out with something stupid that everyone will laugh at.
You never know what he’ll come out with next.

children.name: blurt out
children.definition: to suddenly say sth without thinking, especially sth embarrassing or sth that should be kept secret: thốt ra, buột miệng nói ra
examples: She had blurted out my secret when she was upset, and now everyone knew about it.
He couldn’t go through the agony of lying to them again, so he blurted everything out.

children.name: blurt out that
examples: She couldn’t think of a good excuse, so blurted out that she was pregnant.

children.name: cheer
children.definition: to shout as a way of showing happiness, approval, or support of sb or sth: hoan hô, cổ vũ
examples: At the end, the whole audience stood up clapping and cheering.
The crowd cheered when the band came on stage.
cheer for
I saw the way the crowd cheered for him, and I thought, ‘I want to be like that!’
cheer sbUK
The speaker was cheered loudly when he called for a total ban on nuclear weapons.
cheer sb onencourage sb to do sth by cheering them as they do it
All the mums and dads come to cheer their kids on.

children.name: bark
children.definition: / bark out to shout at someone in a forceful manner :quát tháo
examples: The sergeant barked(out)a succession of orders to the new recruits.

children.name: bark at
examples: ‘Don’t just stand there, give me a hand,’ she barked at the shop assistant.

children.name: to say sth very loudly to get sb's attention
hail
children.definition: slightly formal to call to sb in order to greet them or try to attract their attention :gọi
examples: She leaned out of the window and hailed a passerby.
I tried to hail her from across the room.

children.name: hail a cab/taxi
examples: The hotel doorman will hail a cab for you.
Shall we hail a taxi?

children.name: call
children.definition: to shout loudly because you want to get sb’s attention, to let sb know where you are etc: gọi, hú
examples: Did you call?
"Hey, you! Come over here!" she called.
Someone in the crowd called his name.
Just call me if you need anything. I’m right here.
